final_answer.explanation: Romell Broom, who has been on death row for 34 years, agreed to a DNA test in 2003. This agreement was part of his efforts to prove his innocence regarding the murder, kidnapping, and rape of Tryna Middleton. The DNA test results, however, did not exonerate him, indicating a likelihood of him being the donor at 1 in 2.3 million, meaning that while it did not definitively prove his guilt, it also did not clear him of the charges.

graph.title: Summarize Broom's Case
graph.content: <1230>[Summarize Broom's Case] Extract and summarize the relevant details from the context table regarding Romell Broom's case.</1230>
graph.answer: Romell Broom, born June 4, 1956, is an American man convicted of murder, kidnapping, and rape. He was convicted in 1984 for the abduction and murder of Tryna Middleton, a 14-year-old girl in East Cleveland, Ohio. Broom was on death row for 34 years and 106 days before he agreed to a DNA test in 2003 to prove his innocence. However, the test results did not exonerate him, indicating a likelihood of him being the donor at 1 in 2.3 million, suggesting that eight or nine other black males could have the same DNA profile. Broom has repeatedly requested independent DNA retesting and a change of legal representation.
